instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
Hello. I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that took a heavy blow to the keyboard by some kind of heavy object. There is significant indent in the keyboard around the U, I, J, and K keys and the whole keyboard itself is not functional anymore. I put the board in a new topcase and it turns on, keyboard works, and the board seems to boot but I have no image on internal or external display. Caps lock key works when pressed, USB drive with OSX lights up and flashes when connected, and after about a minute or so, the touchbar turns on. I checked the voltages for the LCD, with the LCD connected ,and have listed them below. <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PANEL_FET_EN_DLY</SIGNAL> are fluctuating between 0-0.5v so thinking maybe there is an issue with <CHIP>U9800</CHIP>? The board is spotless and has no signs of corrosion or other damage that I can see.  

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - Fluctuates between 0 and .5v
<SIGNAL>PANEL_FET_EN_DLY</SIGNAL> - Fluctuates between 0 and .5v
<SIGNAL>DFR_DISP_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>BUF_EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_REST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>DFR_DISP_SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> - 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
Probably broken traces, or solders.
Do you get GPU voltages?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: Yes I do have voltage on all the GPU coils. The indent in the keyboard is very close to where <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> is on the board so its definitely possible there is a broken trace or solder under it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: I pulled <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> and checked continuity between some of the pads and the resistors around it and did not find any broken trace. I replaced <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> from a donor, but still have the same issue. <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> still pulses from 0-0.5v. Do you know what would cause that to pulse?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
You can have problems on GPU, or CPU video output areas.
Still no external video?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
i have one that has the same symptoms. could you check to see if and when the GPU coils start having voltage on them? is it immediately on power-on or not?

sorry to use this thread for this question, but mine doesnt have GPU voltages, so am just asking to see where in the boot-phase it does that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: Yea I still do not have external video. I tried to checked the GPU coils again and now I do not have any voltage on them for some reason. Before replacing <CHIP>U9800</CHIP>, I did have 0.9v on all the GPU coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
Ok so I replaced <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> again and put the original one back on since I did not have another donor, and the GPU rails have voltage again now. I still have the same issue though with no image internal or external. <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> seems to only pulse for a few seconds after I connect the charger and then it just stays at 0v. Not sure what to check next.

Captianmac, the GPU coils on this board do get voltage immediately on boot. Hope this helps you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> seems to only pulse for a few seconds"
Check voltage at pins 44/45 of J8500 at same time.

Also check if <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> pulses.
If not, LCD voltages cannot be maintained.
In such case, try another full LCD assembly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: I do not get anything on pin 44/45 of J8500 and also get nothing on <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL>. I have tried 2 different full display assemblies and still have the same issue with both.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: When I first connect the charger, <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.3v but <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL> is only 2.5v. After a few seconds, <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL> goes to 0v but the enable is still 3.3v. I'm pretty sure <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL> is also supposed to be 3.3v but I am not completely sure on that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL> selects between CPU, or GPU video outputs.
You should check its level on working board, when boots.

<SIGNAL>PANEL_FET_EN_DLY</SIGNAL> pulses at same time with <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
Yea <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL> goes to 3.3v on boot and then goes to 0v after a few seconds and stays at 0v on a good board. 

This board only seems to go to 2.5v for some reason. I tried to connect an external monitor to this board, and still have no external image, and <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL> stays at 0v. <SIGNAL>PANEL_FET_EN_DLY</SIGNAL> is 0v and does not pulse at all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
2.5V is stil valid high level.
But such lower value can point to a problem with <CHIP>U9800</CHIP>/50.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R9856</RESISTOR> is good.

Missing external video also points to <CHIP>U9800</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: Anyone get to the bottom of this? I have one non display external or internal and no power on coils for gpu

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: I have not gotten to the bottom of this yet. I have GPU voltage but no image on mine. I know itâ€™s not <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> since I replaced it with a know good <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> and still no image. I think itâ€™s a PCH issue on mine

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: So as a last resort on this one I put some flux around the PCH and heated it for only about a minute, and now its not booting fully anymore. I get 20v 250ma and seem to have all voltages except for CPU and GPU voltages. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 3.3v and <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is 1.1v but <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is 0v. I noticed that <CHIP>U8605</CHIP> seems to be getting warm now also but I could not find any shorts. I removed the plate/cover on J9600 and the amps drop to 190ma and <CHIP>U8605</CHIP> does not get warm anymore. Could I have done some damage to J9600 during the PCH reflow or could a dead PCH cause this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
